title: Sheet 3F
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">The curving edge of the monstrance seen in sheets 3D and 3E continues into this sheet, where it overlaps the arch of an apse that extends below the head of Christ in sheets 4D, 4E, and 4F. Within the arch are tiny soldiers wearing the uniform of the civil guard; they fire rifles equipped with bayonets. Atop the buttress that supports the arch, several tiny, naked human-animal figures appear to be shooting cannons but are in fact operating theatrical spotlights (see fig. 1 and fig. 2). Electric spotlights began to be used in the 1880s, but the stands and the smoke emanating from these suggest they could also be carbon arc lamps. Their light illuminates several chamber pots falling from the sky in sheet 3G as well as the figure of Neptune (Poseidon in Greek mythology) rising up from the swirling sea (see sheet 3G and folio 3H/I). A grotesque figure also fires a large cannon or spotlight in sheets 4A and 5A (fig. 3).

Here, as in sheet 3D, the outer arcs that once flanked Christ’s head were removed early in the drawing’s history. The paper appears lighter in the areas where the medium was scratched away. In both sheets, Ensor used green colored pencil to enhance the clouds, smoke, and rays of light. SMC/KJN

Ensor’s fascination with the visual energy produced by the contrasts of light and dark and the interaction of his figures within pictorial space is reflected in both this sheet and the print Capture of a Strange Town (fig. 4; see also sheets 3G, 3H/I, 4F, 4G, 4H, and 4I). Indeed, the artist was constantly preoccupied by light and space. Ensor had a strong memory for composition and design; the work of other artists seems to have frequently stuck with him and been integrated into his own oeuvre. Closer consideration of Capture of a Strange Town reveals a probable source for its composition: the mezzotint Belshazzar’s Feast by John Martin, an English Romantic artist and favorite of King Leopold I of Belgium (fig. 5). The explosion of the elements and fantastical landscapes lie at the heart of Martin’s biblical scenes, which exhibit an energy that clearly left its mark on Ensor. The Belgian artist likely saw Martin’s work in Ernest Chesneau’s La peinture anglaise (English Painting; A. Quantin, 1882), as he copied several works from this book. ST
